Award.AwardTitle: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Enhancing SIUC Campus Cyberinfrastructure to Accelerate Data-Driven Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project implements a high-performance research and education network architecture over the existing campus cyberinfrastructure (CI) at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. The project solves the performance bottleneck of the current campus core network and establishes new infrastructures enabling high-throughput data transfer with peer institutions and on-campus private wireless broadband service. The updated CI enables efficient and high-throughput data movement needed by fast-growing data-intensive research and education applications across broad academic domains on campus including Chemistry and Biochemistry, Physics, Engineering, Plant Biology, Statistics, Computer Science, etc. The project builds upon a strong partnership among campus information technology experts, networking faculties, and domain researchers. It also provides an exceptional opportunity to train the CI workforce. <br/><br/>The project includes three tasks: 1) enhance the campus core network by adding redundancy across 9 core locations with new routers and 10 Gbps links. The updates add the capacity and redundancy needed to offer reliable and high-performance network service to the whole campus; 2) establish a Science DMZ and the associated network performance monitoring framework, which enables researchers to obtain and share data with external hosts a high speed; and 3) establish a private LTE network dedicated to research and education over the 3.65 GHz CBRS spectrum. Five data-intensive science and education applications are prototyped to demonstrate the new CI capabilities and workflows enabled by this project.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "CC* Networking Infrastructure: Enhancing SIUC Campus Cyberinfrastructure to Accelerate Data-Driven Research and Education" project, funded by the National Science Foundation, was undertaken to address critical limitations within the existing campus cyberinfrastructure at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. This initiative has successfully improved network performance, established a simple Science DMZ for high-speed data sharing, and introduced a private LTE network dedicated to research and education. These advancements have significantly enhanced the capabilities of the university's cyberinfrastructure, allowing for the efficient transfer of high-throughput data vital for the growing demands of data-intensive research and education applications across various academic disciplines.

The project's outcomes include:

1. Enhancement of Campus Core Network

The project has enhanced the campus core network by adding redundancy across nine core locations through the introduction of new routers and 10 Gbps links. This update has substantially increased the network's capacity and redundancy, ensuring the provision of reliable and high-performance network services throughout the entire campus. This enhanced infrastructure has been leveraged to support virtualized learning environments, such as NETLAB+, enabling customized and preconfigured learning content and virtualized systems used in a multitude of ITEC courses.

2. Establishment of a Science DMZ

A Science Demilitarized Zone (Science DMZ) has been established, along with an associated network performance monitoring framework, allowing researchers to efficiently acquire and share data with external hosts at high speeds. This development has proven particularly valuable for the SIU Wabash seismograph site, located approximately two hours from campus, potentially enabling the remote collection of seismic data in the future.

3. Creation of a Private LTE Network

The project has successfully created a private Long-Term Evolution (LTE) network dedicated to research and education, utilizing the 3.65 GHz Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) spectrum. Two LTE stations have been deployed to support the ongoing campus lake water quality monitoring project. The potential for integration with other LTE deployments on the SIU campus holds promise for broader private LTE coverage, especially for initiatives such as the forest monitoring project.

4. Prototyping Data-Intensive Science and Education Applications

As a culmination of the project, five data-intensive science and education applications have been prototyped, effectively demonstrating the new capabilities and workflows made possible by the enhanced cyberinfrastructure. The project has also supported a total of at least four graduate students and one undergraduate student, providing the necessary resources for hardware, LTE station configurations, and research support in various data-driven science and engineering research endeavors including enviormental engineering, earthquake detection, networking, machine learning etc. 

This NSF-funded project represents a transformative initiative that not only addresses the immediate performance bottlenecks within the existing infrastructure but also lays the foundation for continued growth in data-intensive research and education. Furthermore, it has fostered interdisciplinary collaboration and training opportunities, making it a valuable asset to Southern Illinois University Carbondale.
